MRS. MARTIN @ CMS: OVERSEEN . . .

We recently ran across Mrs. Martin working remotely with her class of students at Carbondale Middle School.

"My high-high is when my students shared their 'All About Me' slideshows with their class," shared Mrs. Martin who is in her 31st year of teaching, her fifth in the district.

"They went above and beyond," Ms. Martin continued. "Most of them were much more creative than the model I shared with them. I learned so much about them! For example, many of them love sushi just like me. One student's father owns a candy store! Many of them took pictures of artwork they had done and put it in their show. One student included a map with all the places they have traveled highlighted. Another student shared pictures of a sunset because they make them feel peaceful. I also learned that a student has a goal of becoming a famous ballerina."

She said she and the students are learning to better use the technology: "Some of them have become the teacher and taught me a thing or two about technology!"

#CES95Proud

CONGRATS, 'VIRTUAL BOSTON MARATHONER!'

Over the next few days, would-be Boston Marathoners are celebrating what would have been the big event by logging their miles and times in their own respective homes.

One of those who has already logged her time and hours is Lewis teacher Mrs. Jenkins: She ran the Marathon's 26.2 miles in four hours and 32 minutes to compete in the 'virtual marathon.'

Mrs. Jenkins said she qualified to run in the Boston Marathon in 2018 with a time of 3 hours and 28 minutes.

"Monday’s marathon was my fourth full marathon," she shared. "My first was in 2014. I’ve also done 10 half marathons. I love running because it lets me challenge myself. I love setting/achieving goals and doing things I didn’t think I was capable of. I also love being outside and exploring new places."

We're just impressed: Congrats to you!

#CES95Proud
www.ces95.org

(Photo courtesy of Mrs. Jenkins)

DISTRICT'S MEAL PROGRAM STARTS TOMORROW

Caught up with District #95's Food Services staff ~ Mrs. Wyatt, Ms. Danielle and Ms. Melissa ~ stacking bags for meal deliveries, starting at 12 noon tomorrow, Wednesday, August 19.

Some things parents need to know:
* Individuals will need to go to their closest Meal Bus stop to pick up their meals (see the District's website for locations), between 12 noon and 2:30 p.m. on Monday, Wednesday and Friday.
* The Meal Bus will be at each stop for 15 minutes.
* It is best to be at your Meal Bus stop at the beginning of the 15-minute scheduled stop.
* Meal Buses will drive each route only once.
* Meals are specifically assigned to each registered District #95 student: Those picking up a meal for a child will need to have the student's name and school.
* Individuals can pick up their student's meal at the "Grab & Go" at Thomas Elementary School, from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. Monday, Wednesday and Friday.
* For questions about the Meal Deliveries, call the Meal Bus dispatch at 855.527.6171 or 618.201.0521.

#CES95Proud

SUPT. BOOTH DISCUSSES 'RACE' AND RACE RELATIONS WITH THE IPA

In a frank and open discussion, Supt. Daniel Booth shares about race and race relations in this current climate of racial tension, in a talk with Illinois Principal Association Executive Director Dr. Jason Leahy.

In the past few weeks, Supt. Booth said he has had answered questions and had frank discussions with at least a dozen of his non-African American colleagues across the state on this issue.

"I have heard deep reflecting occurring" in these conversations, Supt. Booth said. "This is a great moment in time when we can recognize, when ... the scales fall off our eyes and we are able to see things in a different light."

He suggests that educators be reflective, as opposed to feeling guilt and educate themselves on issues that they don't understand and for African American educators to help their non-black colleagues understand African American experiences ~ which have similarities and differences ~ "with grace and mercy."

Video link: https://youtu.be/hcXA0EdbC_Y

#CES95Proud

THIS IS SECOND STEP

Latasha Schraeder, the District's Assistant Superintendent for Pupil Services, shows off the teacher binders for the Second Step socio-emotional learning curriculum starting in the new school year.

Second Step has been chosen as the curriculum to be used districtwide as the primary tool to encourage students’ social and emotional growth; teachers will teach the curriculum to their students.

"The implementation of Second Step will provide continuity in the social and emotional curriculum offered to our students in the classroom on a weekly basis and allow our social workers and school counselors more time to meet the needs of students requiring more intensive, individualized support," Mrs. Schraeder says.

This week, district teachers will begin to pick up the Second Step curriculum materials.

NEW TECHNOLOGY DIRECTOR VISITS DISTRICT #95

Today saw Melody Spaulding, District #95's new Director of Technology, visit the district. She was hired by the Board of Education at its May board meeting.

Mrs. Spaulding comes to District #95 from Egyptian School District, in Tamms, where she was its Technology Coordinator.

She said she was attracted to Carbondale because it's "a place to grow."

"I really want to work with the teachers more and incorporate technology into their curriculum," she said.

When not working, she helps her husband on a 7,000-acre row farm and a 200-head beef cattle operations. The couple has three children, the youngest of whom graduated in the Class of 2020.

Welcome to District #95, Mrs. Spaulding!

BIDDING ADIEU TO 125-PLUS YEARS

During Thursday night's virtual Board of Education meeting, School Supt. Daniel Booth acknowledged six retiring educators for their years of service to students in District #95:

Kathy Bell, 24 years

Michelle Garthe, 27 years

Ann Hamman, 14 years

Angela Jenkins, 28 years

Tari Moorman, 20 years; and,

Paula Sierfert, 13 years in the district and another 14 working with District schools

(Also pictured here, and retiring, is Food Services cook Stella Lasley, who also announced her retirement.)

Supt. Booth said there was no amount of money that could be paid to replace the experience of the retiring educators. All together, their careers with the district total about 125 years.

"We know that this year did not end and their career did not end the way that they expected it to," Supt. Booth said, "but is is another chapter (in) the book that I'm sure all of them can write on their years in education ..."

#CES95Proud
